qr-generator.noContent: Enter content to generate a QR code

seoContent.heading: Free QR Code Generator Online
seoContent.body: Our QR code generator lets you create QR codes quickly and free, right in your browser. Just enter text, a URL, phone number or any data, and the tool will generate a ready-to-download QR code as PNG. A QR code (Quick Response) is a two-dimensional barcode that stores information in a black-and-white pattern. QR codes can be read by smartphone cameras and barcode scanners, making them ideal for sharing information fast.

seoContent.heading: What are QR codes used for?

items.title: Links and websites
items.body: Encode a URL so users can open a webpage quickly after scanning the code.

items.title: WiFi
items.body: Share WiFi details with guests - after scanning, the phone connects to the network automatically.

items.title: Contact details
items.body: Encode a vCard with name, phone and email in a single QR code.

items.title: Marketing and advertising
items.body: Place QR codes on flyers, posters and packaging to direct customers to offers, product pages or social media.

seoContent.heading: How to create effective QR codes?
items: **Right size** - A QR code should be at least 2√ó2 cm for print. For billboards use at least 256√ó256 px.
**High contrast** - Keep a dark pattern on a light background. Avoid low colour contrast.
**Test before printing** - Always scan the code with different devices before printing.
**Short URLs** - The less data, the simpler and more readable the QR code.
**Quiet zone** - Leave an empty margin around the code so scanners can read it easily.

items.a: Static QR codes (like those from our tool) never expire. They contain data directly in the code, so they work as long as the encoded data is valid.

items.q: What is the maximum QR code capacity?
items.a: A QR code can store up to 4,296 alphanumeric characters, 7,089 digits or 2,953 bytes of binary data. Shorter data produces a simpler, easier-to-scan code.
Yes, our QR code generator is completely free with no limits. You can create any number of QR codes without registering.

items.q: Can I use QR codes commercially?
items.a: Of course! You can use the generated QR codes for any purpose - personal or commercial, in print or digital.

seoContent.body: Our QR code generator runs entirely in your browser. Your data is not sent to any server - generation happens locally on your device.

items.a: Stuck pixels can sometimes be fixed with special apps. Dead pixels (fully dark) usually cannot be fixed with software.

caesar-cipher.title: Caesar Cipher
caesar-cipher.subtitle: Encrypt and decrypt text with letter shifting

seoContent.heading: Caesar Cipher Online - Encrypt and Decrypt
seoContent.body: The Caesar cipher is one of the oldest and simplest substitution ciphers in the history of cryptography. It is named after Julius Caesar, who used it to encrypt military correspondence. Each letter in the text is shifted by a fixed number of positions in the alphabet.

seoContent.heading: How does the Caesar cipher work?
seoContent.body: The Caesar cipher shifts every letter in the text by a fixed number of positions in the alphabet. For example with a shift of 3: A‚ÜíD, B‚ÜíE, C‚ÜíF, etc. Decryption is shifting in the opposite direction.

items.title: Shift +1
items.body: ABC ‚Üí BCD

items.title: Shift +3 (Caesar)
items.body: ABC ‚Üí DEF

items.title: Shift +13 (ROT13)
items.body: ABC ‚Üí NOP

items.title: Shift +25
items.body: ABC ‚Üí ZAB

seoContent.heading: What is the Caesar cipher used for?
items: **Education** - Learning cryptography and algorithms
**Puzzles and games** - Creating secret messages
**Geocaching** - Encrypting clues in outdoor games
**Escape rooms** - Logic puzzle element
**History** - Understanding the roots of cryptography

seoContent.heading: What is ROT13?
seoContent.body: ROT13 is a special case of the Caesar cipher with a shift of 13. Because the Latin alphabet has 26 letters, applying ROT13 twice restores the original text. ROT13 is often used online to hide spoilers and jokes.

items.a: No, the Caesar cipher is easy to break - there are only 25 possible shifts. It's for learning cryptography, not protecting data.

seoContent.heading: What is an online metronome?
seoContent.body: A metronome is a device or tool used to keep time in music. Our free online metronome works directly in your browser and allows you to set a precise tempo ranging from 20 to 300 BPM (beats per minute). It is the perfect tool for both beginner musicians and professionals who want to improve their sense of rhythm and timing.

seoContent.heading: How to use the online metronome?
seoContent.body: Using our metronome is simple. Set the desired tempo using the slider or type a BPM value manually. Choose a time signature (e.g. 4/4, 3/4, 6/8), then press Start. The metronome will begin keeping time with a clear accent on the first beat of each measure. You can also use the Tap Tempo feature ‚Äî tap the button at your desired speed and the metronome will automatically detect the BPM.

items.title: Largo (40-60 BPM)
items.body: Very slow and broad tempo. Majestic and solemn. Often found in classical adagios and ceremonial pieces.

items.title: Adagio (60-76 BPM)
items.body: Slow and expressive tempo. Calm and full of emotion. Popular in ballads and slow sonata movements.

items.title: Andante (76-108 BPM)
items.body: Moderate walking pace tempo. Natural and comfortable for many musical styles and genres.

items.title: Moderato (108-120 BPM)
items.body: Moderately fast tempo. The sweet spot, commonly used in pop, rock and many other genres.

items.title: Allegro (120-156 BPM)
items.body: Fast and energetic tempo. Dominant in many genres from classical to dance music.

items.title: Vivace (156-176 BPM)
items.body: Lively and animated tempo. Gives pieces a joyful and exhilarating character.

items.title: Presto (168-200 BPM)
items.body: Very fast tempo requiring advanced technique. Found in finales and virtuosic compositions.

seoContent.heading: What is a metronome used for?
items: **Instrument practice** - Maintain steady tempo while learning new pieces on guitar, piano, drums or violin
**Vocal training** - Develop your sense of rhythm and vocal precision by practicing with a metronome
**Band rehearsals** - Synchronize all musicians by playing to a shared tempo reference
**Dance practice** - Keep a regular beat during dance exercises and choreography rehearsals
**Sports training** - Maintain consistent pace during running, cardio workouts or yoga
**Speech therapy and rehabilitation** - Rhythmic metronome exercises support speech therapy and motor coordination

seoContent.heading: What is BPM?
seoContent.body: BPM (Beats Per Minute) is the unit of measuring musical tempo, indicating the number of beats per minute. The higher the BPM value, the faster the tempo. For example, a ballad typically has 60-80 BPM, pop music hovers around 100-130 BPM, while techno and drum and bass can reach 160-180 BPM. Our metronome lets you set the tempo anywhere from 20 to 300 BPM.

items.q: Is an online metronome as accurate as a physical one?
items.a: Yes, our metronome uses the Web Audio API which provides millisecond-level accuracy. This is more precise than many cheap mechanical metronomes.

A time signature defines how beats are grouped in a measure. The most common are 4/4 (four quarter notes per measure), 3/4 (waltz time) and 6/8 (two main beats with triplet subdivisions). The top number indicates beats per measure, the bottom number indicates the note value.

items.q: How does the Tap Tempo feature work?
items.a: Tap the Tap button at your desired tempo. The metronome analyzes the intervals between taps and automatically calculates the average BPM. The more taps you make, the more accurate the result.

items.q: What tempo is suitable for beginners?
items.a: Start with a slow tempo (60-80 BPM) and gradually increase it. Precision is more important than speed. Once you master a piece at a slow tempo, you can move to a faster one.

items.q: Do I need to install any app?
items.a: No, our metronome works directly in your web browser. It requires no installation, registration or file downloads.

seoContent.heading: What is tarot?
seoContent.body: Tarot is a system of 78 cards used for centuries for reflection, meditation and seeking inner answers. The deck has two main groups: 22 Major Arcana cards, which symbolise important life themes and archetypes, and 56 Minor Arcana cards in four suits: Cups, Pentacles, Swords and Wands. Our tool draws a card from the full 78-card deck, upright or reversed, and shows its meaning.

seoContent.heading: Major Arcana - 22 cards of fate
seoContent.body: The Major Arcana are 22 cards numbered from 0 (The Fool) to 21 (The World). They represent major life themes, spiritual lessons and archetypes - from the Fool's innocence, through Death's transformation, to The World's fulfilment. They include: The Fool, The Magician, The High Priestess, The Empress, The Emperor, The Hierophant, The Lovers, The Chariot, Strength, The Hermit, Wheel of Fortune, Justice, The Hanged Man, Death, Temperance, The Devil, The Tower, The Star, The Moon, The Sun, Judgement and The World.

seoContent.heading: Minor Arcana - 56 cards of daily life
items: **Cups** - Emotions, feelings, relationships, intuition (water element)
**Pentacles** - Finance, work, health, material world (earth element)
**Swords** - Thoughts, conflict, communication, intellect (air element)
**Wands** - Passion, energy, creativity, action (fire element)

seoContent.heading: Upright vs reversed
seoContent.body: Each tarot card can appear in two positions: upright and reversed. Upright usually indicates the positive or direct meaning of the card, while reversed can suggest blocks, challenges or inner aspects of the theme. A reversed card does not always mean something negative - it often invites deeper reflection.

seoContent.heading: How to use the tarot card draw?
items: Focus on a question or theme that matters to you
Click "Draw a Card" - a random card from the full 78-card deck will be chosen
Click the card to flip it and see which card you drew
Read the meaning for the drawn position (upright or reversed)
Reflect on how the card's message relates to your question

items.a: Yes, the tool is completely free and requires no registration.

items.q: How many cards are in the deck?
items.a: Our deck has the full 78 cards - 22 Major Arcana and 56 Minor Arcana (Cups, Pentacles, Swords, Wands).

seoContent.heading: Sleep Calculator Online - Find Your Optimal Sleep Time
seoContent.body: Our free sleep calculator helps you find the best bedtime or wake-up time based on 90-minute sleep cycles. Waking at the right point in your sleep cycle helps you feel rested and energised.

items.title: Stage 1 - Falling asleep
items.body: Light sleep, easy to wake. Lasts 5-10 minutes.

items.title: Stage 2 - Light sleep
items.body: Body temperature drops, heart rate slows. ~20 min.

items.title: Stage 3 - Deep sleep
items.body: Body recovery, tissue repair. Hardest to wake from.

items.title: REM stage
items.body: Dreaming, memory processing. ~90 min full cycle.

seoContent.heading: How much sleep do you need?
Sleep hygiene tips
items: **Regular schedule** - Go to bed and wake at the same time
**Dark bedroom** - Use curtains or an eye mask
**No screens** - Put your phone away at least 30 min before bed
**Right temperature** - Keep the bedroom at 18-20¬∞C
**Avoid caffeine** - No coffee at least 6 hours before bed

items.q: Why is the sleep cycle 90 minutes?
items.a: 90 minutes is the average time for one full sleep cycle (through all stages). It can vary from 80 to 120 minutes.

items.q: How many sleep cycles do I need?
items.a: Adults need 5-6 full cycles (7.5-9 hours). At least 4 cycles (6 hours) to function properly.

seoContent.heading: What are BMR and TDEE?
seoContent.body: BMR (Basal Metabolic Rate) is the calories you burn at rest - the energy needed for basic bodily functions. TDEE (Total Daily Energy Expenditure) is BMR plus calories burned through physical activity. We use TDEE for diet planning.

Main energy source, fuel for brain and muscles

items.q: What is the difference between BMR and TDEE?
items.a: BMR is calories burned at rest. TDEE is BMR plus calories from physical activity and digestion. We use TDEE for diet planning.

seoContent.heading: Blood Type Calculator - Work Out Your Child's Blood Type
seoContent.body: Our blood type calculator works out the probability of each blood type for a child based on the parents' blood types. It uses ABO system and Rh factor inheritance according to Mendelian genetics.

seoContent.heading: How does blood type inheritance work?
seoContent.body: Blood type is determined by genes inherited from both parents. The ABO system has three alleles: A, B and O. A and B are dominant over O. The Rh factor (+ or -) is inherited independently - the Rh+ allele is dominant over Rh-.

items.q: Can two type O parents have a child with a different blood type?
items.a: No. Both parents with type O have genotype OO, so the child can only inherit O - they will have type O.
The calculator shows probabilities based on standard genetics. In very rare cases, genetic mutations can give unexpected results.
The Rh factor is a protein on the surface of red blood cells. Rh+ (present) is dominant over Rh- (absent). About 85% of the population is Rh+.

seoContent.heading: Inflation Calculator - Work Out Purchasing Power
seoContent.body: Our inflation calculator shows how inflation affects the value of your money over time. See what your savings will be worth in 5, 10 or 20 years at different inflation rates. View the loss of purchasing power year by year.

seoContent.heading: How does inflation work?
seoContent.body: Inflation is a rise in the general level of prices in the economy. That means the same amount of money buys less over time. Inflation of 5% per year means that after 10 years your $1000 will be worth only about $614 in today's prices.

seoContent.heading: How to protect savings from inflation?
items: **Savings accounts** - Basic protection, but often below inflation
**Government bonds** - Inflation-linked bonds protect capital
**Stocks** - Tend to outpace inflation over the long term
**Property** - Property prices usually rise with inflation
**Gold and precious metals** - Traditional inflation hedge

items.q: What is the current inflation rate?
items.a: The current inflation rate changes every month. Check your country's official statistics office (e.g. BLS in the US, ONS in the UK).
Inflation reduces the purchasing power of savings. If your money doesn't grow faster than inflation, you lose real value.
Moderate inflation (2-3%) is considered healthy for the economy. Deflation (falling prices) can lead to recession.

dog-years-calculator.subtitle: Convert your dog's age to human years

seoContent.heading: Dog Years to Human Years - Dog Age Calculator
seoContent.body: Our dog years calculator converts your dog's age to human years and takes size into account. The "multiply by 7" rule is a simplification - dogs actually age faster early in life and then slow down. Small dogs tend to live longer than large dogs.

seoContent.heading: Why "multiply by 7" is a myth
seoContent.body: The rule "1 dog year = 7 human years" is too simple. A 1-year-old dog is much more mature than a 7-year-old child. Modern formulas reflect that dogs age in a non-linear way - faster when young and slower in later years.

seoContent.heading: Dog life stages
items: **Puppy (0-1 year)** - Rapid growth and development
**Junior (1-2 years)** - Maturing, full of energy
**Adult (2-7 years)** - Prime years
**Senior (7-10 years)** - Slowing down, needs more care
**Geriatric (10+ years)** - Special diet and care

items.a: Yes, large and giant breeds age faster than small ones. A Chihuahua may live 15-20 years, while a Great Dane often lives 7-10 years.
It depends on size: small dogs become seniors around 10, medium around 8, large around 6, giant around 5.

seoContent.heading: Roman Numerals - Converter and Calculator Online
seoContent.body: Our free Roman numerals converter lets you switch quickly between Arabic (1, 2, 3...) and Roman (I, II, III...). Enter an Arabic or Roman number and the calculator converts it. It supports numbers from 1 to 3999.

seoContent.heading: How does subtractive notation work?
seoContent.body: When a smaller symbol appears before a larger one, we subtract its value. For example: IV = 5-1 = 4, IX = 10-1 = 9, XL = 50-10 = 40, XC = 100-10 = 90, CD = 500-100 = 400, CM = 1000-100 = 900.

seoContent.heading: Where are Roman numerals used today?
items: **Clocks** - Clock faces often use Roman numerals
**Book chapters** - Chapter and volume numbering
**Dates** - Years on buildings, films (e.g. MMXXVI = 2026)
**Monarchs and popes** - Elizabeth II, John Paul II
**Events** - Super Bowl LVIII, Olympic Games XXXIII

items.a: In the standard system there is no symbol for 5000. Larger numbers need special notation (e.g. vinculum = √ó1000).

items.q: Is 4 written as IIII or IV?
items.a: Both are correct. IV (subtractive) is more common, but IIII appears on many clocks.

items.q: Is there a symbol for zero?
items.a: No. The Romans did not have a concept of zero as a number. Their system was additive and did not need a symbol for nothing.

seoContent.heading: Why multiply by 7 doesn't work
seoContent.body: A 1-year-old cat is more mature than a 7-year-old child. According to AAHA, a cat after the first year is roughly equivalent to a 15-year-old human, and after the second year to a 24-year-old. Each additional year is about 4 human years.

items.q: How long do cats usually live?
items.a: Indoor cats live on average 12-18 years. Outdoor cats tend to live shorter (10-12 years) due to risks.

items.q: What is the oldest cat on record?
items.a: The oldest documented cat was Creme Puff from Texas, who lived 38 years and 3 days (1967-2005).

items.q: How can I help my cat live longer?
items.a: Regular vet check-ups, a healthy diet, keeping a healthy weight, and mental and physical activity.

fuel-calculator.subtitle: Calculate fuel consumption and energy usage for combustion and electric vehicles

seoContent.heading: Online fuel consumption calculator
seoContent.body: Our free fuel consumption calculator lets you quickly calculate fuel usage in liters per 100 km (L/100km) or miles per gallon (MPG) and optionally estimate trip costs. It supports both combustion vehicles (petrol, diesel, LPG) and electric vehicles (EVs). Simply enter the distance traveled and fuel or energy consumed ‚Äî the fuel/electricity price is optional and only needed if you want cost estimates.

seoContent.heading: How to calculate fuel consumption?
seoContent.body: Fuel consumption is expressed in liters per 100 km (L/100km) in the metric system, or miles per gallon (MPG) in the imperial system. The metric formula is: consumption = (fuel used in liters / distance in km) x 100. For example, if you used 35 liters of petrol over 500 km, your consumption is (35 / 500) x 100 = 7.0 L/100km. For electric vehicles, the same formula applies using kWh instead of liters.

seoContent.heading: MPG vs L/100km ‚Äî imperial and metric conversion
seoContent.body: Miles per gallon (MPG) is the standard fuel economy measure in the US and UK, while L/100km is used in most of the rest of the world. The conversion formula is: MPG = 235.215 / (L/100km). For example, 7 L/100km equals about 33.6 MPG, and 30 MPG equals about 7.84 L/100km. Our calculator supports both systems ‚Äî simply toggle between Metric and Imperial modes to see results in your preferred units.

seoContent.heading: Typical fuel and energy consumption by vehicle type

items.title: City car (petrol)
items.body: 5-7 L/100km (34-47 MPG) ‚Äî small, economical cars like Fiat 500, Toyota Yaris

items.title: Sedan / estate (petrol)
items.body: 7-10 L/100km (24-34 MPG) ‚Äî mid-size family cars like Toyota Corolla, Skoda Octavia

items.title: SUV / crossover (diesel)
items.body: 6-9 L/100km (26-39 MPG) ‚Äî larger vehicles like Kia Sportage, VW Tiguan

items.title: Hybrid (HEV)
items.body: 4-6 L/100km (39-59 MPG) ‚Äî Toyota Prius, Hyundai Ioniq Hybrid

items.title: Plug-in hybrid (PHEV)
items.body: 1-3 L/100km (78-235 MPG*) ‚Äî electric and combustion modes combined

items.title: Electric vehicle (EV)
items.body: 14-20 kWh/100km (3.1-4.4 mi/kWh) ‚Äî Tesla Model 3, VW ID.3, Hyundai Ioniq 5

seoContent.heading: Electric vehicles ‚Äî energy consumption
seoContent.body: Energy consumption in electric vehicles is measured in kWh per 100 km (kWh/100km) or miles per kWh. A typical EV uses 14 to 22 kWh/100km (2.8-4.4 mi/kWh), depending on vehicle weight, driving style, and weather conditions. At an electricity price of around $0.20/kWh, driving 100 km in an EV costs $2.80-4.40, while a combustion car (7 L/100km at $1.60/L) costs about $11.20. That is a 60-75% saving on fuel costs.

seoContent.heading: How to reduce fuel consumption?
items: **Smooth driving** ‚Äî avoid harsh acceleration and braking, maintain a steady speed
**Proper tire pressure** ‚Äî under-inflated tires increase rolling resistance and fuel use by 5-10%
**Reduce highway speed** ‚Äî driving at 65 mph instead of 75 mph can cut consumption by 15-20%
**Turn off unnecessary systems** ‚Äî air conditioning can add 0.5-1 L/100km (1-2 MPG drop) to fuel use
**Regular maintenance** ‚Äî changing filters, oil and spark plugs keeps the engine at peak efficiency
**Reduce weight** ‚Äî remove unnecessary items from the trunk and detach roof racks when not in use
**Drive at optimal RPM** ‚Äî for petrol engines this is 2000-2500 RPM, for diesel 1500-2000 RPM

items.q: How do I calculate my car's fuel consumption?
items.a: Fill the tank, reset the trip meter, drive your usual route, then fill up again. Consumption = (liters at second fill / km driven) x 100, or for MPG: miles driven / gallons used. Our calculator does the math for you.

items.q: What is MPG and how does it relate to L/100km?
items.a: MPG (miles per gallon) measures how many miles you can drive on one gallon of fuel. L/100km measures how many liters you need for 100 km. They are inversely related: MPG = 235.215 / L/100km. Higher MPG means better economy, while lower L/100km means better economy.
No, the price field is optional. If you only want to know your consumption (L/100km or MPG), just enter distance and fuel used. Cost calculations only appear when you provide a price.

items.q: Is an electric car cheaper to run?
items.a: Yes, energy cost per mile is 3-4 times lower than fuel. EVs also have lower maintenance costs (no oil, filters, clutch). The main expense is the purchase price and potential battery replacement.

items.q: How do I calculate trip cost?
items.a: Cost = (consumption L/100km / 100) x distance km x fuel price per liter. E.g. at 7 L/100km, 300 km trip, $1.60/L: (7/100) x 300 x 1.60 = $33.60. Leave the price field empty if you only need consumption figures.

seoContent.heading: Electricity Cost Calculator - Work Out Your Energy Bill
seoContent.body: Our electricity calculator lets you quickly work out how much it costs to run any electrical appliance. Simply enter the appliance wattage, hours of use per day, and your electricity price per kWh. The calculator shows daily, monthly, and yearly energy costs so you can easily see which appliances are costing you the most.

seoContent.heading: How to calculate electricity cost
seoContent.body: Electricity cost is calculated by multiplying the appliance power (in kilowatts) by the usage time (in hours) and the price per kWh. Formula: **Cost = (Power [W] / 1000) x Time [h] x Price [per kWh]**. For example, a 2000W heater running 5 hours a day at $0.30/kWh uses 10 kWh and costs $3.00 per day, or about $90 per month.

seoContent.heading: Electricity usage of common household appliances
Tips to reduce your electricity bill
items: **Switch to LED bulbs** - They use up to 80% less energy than traditional bulbs
**Unplug standby devices** - Standby mode still draws power (so-called energy vampires)
**Use off-peak tariffs** - Electricity is cheaper at night on time-of-use plans
**Choose A+++ rated appliances** - Modern appliances use significantly less energy
**Limit air conditioning** - It is one of the most energy-hungry household appliances
**Cook with the lid on** - Saves up to 30% of energy when cooking on an electric hob
**Wash clothes at 30¬∞C** - Most laundry does not need higher temperatures

items.q: How much does electricity cost per kWh?
items.a: Electricity prices vary by country and provider. In the US, the average is about $0.16/kWh; in the UK around ¬£0.28/kWh; in the EU roughly ‚Ç¨0.25/kWh. Check your latest utility bill for your exact rate.
A kilowatt-hour (kWh) is a unit of energy. 1 kWh means using 1 kilowatt of power for 1 hour. For example, a 100W bulb running for 10 hours uses 1 kWh (100W x 10h = 1000 Wh = 1 kWh).

items.q: What uses the most electricity in a home?
items.a: Heating and cooling systems, electric water heaters, ovens, and tumble dryers are typically the biggest consumers. Always-on appliances like fridges also add up over time.

items.q: How can I read my electricity meter?
items.a: Digital meters display your consumption in kWh on the screen. Smart meters send readings automatically to your provider. For dual-rate meters, there will be two readings (peak and off-peak).

items.q: How much electricity does an average home use?
items.a: In the US, the average household uses about 10,500 kWh per year. In the UK it is around 2,900 kWh, and in the EU roughly 3,500 kWh. Usage depends on household size, appliances, and climate.
